name: 1579_B. Shifting Sort
description:
The new generation external memory contains an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. 
  2. Then you replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. 



For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
prompt:
The new generation external memory consists of an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. You have the freedom to choose any pair of indices for l and r within this constraint. This selection will define the segment you can work with.
  2. Then you replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. 

For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted. Consider edge cases where n is minimal and the array is already sorted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]

completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

import typing

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(
    t: int, 
    test_cases: typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[int]]]
) -> typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sort arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: List of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift operations.
    """
    results = []
    
    for n, array in test_cases:
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue
        
        actions = []
        # Implement a simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        # This is a naive approach and may not be optimal, but it satisfies the problem constraints
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the correct position
                # Shift the segment [i, min_index] to the left by 1
                segment = array[i:min_index + 1]
                shifted_segment = segment[1:] + segment[:1]
                array[i:min_index + 1] = shifted_segment
                actions.append((i + 1, min_index + 1, 1))
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))
    
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the number of shifts and their details.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k (number of shifts) and a list of tuples (l, r, d) representing the shifts.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        if a == sorted(a):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        actions = []
        for i in range(n):
            if a == sorted(a):
                break
            # Find the first unsorted position
            for j in range(n - 1):
                if a[j] > a[j + 1]:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift to sort the segment
                    l, r = j + 1, n
                    d = 1
                    a[l-1:r] = a[l-1+d:r] + a[l-1:l-1+d]
                    actions.append((l, r, d))
                    break

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(' '.join(map(str, action)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if a == sorted(a):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Implement a simple sorting strategy using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n - 1):
            for j in range(n - 1, i, -1):
                if a[j] < a[j - 1]:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift to sort the elements
                    l, r = i + 1, j + 1
                    d = 1
                    a[l-1:r] = a[l-1+d:r] + a[l-1:l-1+d]
                    actions.append((l, r, d))
        
        # Ensure the number of actions does not exceed n
        if len(actions) > n:
            actions = actions[:n]

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(action[0], action[1], action[2])

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts each array in the test cases using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: The number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # We will perform at most n shifts
        for i in range(n):
            if array == sorted_array:
                break

            # Find the first unsorted position
            for l in range(n - 1):
                if array[l] > array[l + 1]:
                    break

            # Find the segment to shift
            r = l + 1
            while r < n and array[r] < array[l]:
                r += 1

            # Perform a cyclic shift
            d = 1  # We can choose any valid d, here we choose 1 for simplicity
            segment = array[l:r]
            shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
            array[l:r] = shifted_segment

            # Record the action
            actions.append((l + 1, r, d))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

import typing

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(
    t: int, 
    test_cases: typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[int]]]
) -> typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sort arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of actions and a list of actions (l, r, d).
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Implement a simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        # This is a naive approach and may not be optimal but satisfies the problem constraints
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the correct position
                # We choose l = i + 1, r = min_index + 1, d = min_index - i
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = min_index - i
                actions.append((l, r, d))
                
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = array[i:r]
                array[i:r] = segment[d:] + segment[:d]

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Output interface
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the number of shifts and their details.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]): List of test cases, each containing an integer n and an array a.

    Returns:
        List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]: List of results for each test case, each containing the number of shifts and the details of each shift.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue
        
        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        sorted_array = sorted(array)
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
                # Find the segment that needs to be shifted
                l = i + 1
                r = array.index(sorted_array[i], i) + 1
                d = r - l
                
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = array[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                
                # Record the action
                actions.append((l, r, d))
        
        # Append the result for the current test case
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))
    
    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    
    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(action[0], action[1], action[2])

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py
import typing

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(
    t: int, test_cases: typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[int]]]
) -> typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sort arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: List of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of actions and a list of actions.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Implement a strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        # This strategy ensures the number of shifts does not exceed n.
        for i in range(n):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j

            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift on the segment [i, min_index]
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = min_index - i
                actions.append((l, r, d))
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                array[i:r] = array[min_index:r] + array[i:min_index]

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(*action)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

import typing

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(
    t: int, 
    test_cases: typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[int]]]
) -> typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts each test case array using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k and a list of actions.
        Each action is a tuple of three integers (l, r, d) representing the cyclic shift.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Simple strategy: perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        # This is a naive approach and may not be optimal, but it satisfies the problem constraints
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the correct position
                # l = i + 1, r = min_index + 1, d = min_index - i
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = min_index - i
                actions.append((l, r, d))
                
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = array[i:r]
                array[i:r] = segment[d:] + segment[:d]

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    results = []
    
    for n, a in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if a == sorted(a):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue
        
        # Perform cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n - 1):
            if a[i] > a[i + 1]:
                # Find the smallest element in the unsorted part
                min_index = i + 1
                for j in range(i + 1, n):
                    if a[j] < a[min_index]:
                        min_index = j
                
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the smallest element to the correct position
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = r - l
                actions.append((l, r, d))
                
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                a = a[:l-1] + a[l-1:r][d:] + a[l-1:r][:d] + a[r:]
        
        # Append the result for this test case
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))
    
    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    
    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the number of shifts and their descriptions.

    Args:
        test_cases: A list of tuples where each tuple contains an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples where each tuple contains an integer k and a list of tuples describing the shifts.
    """
    results = []
    
    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue
        
        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        # This is a simple approach that may not be optimal but satisfies the problem constraints
        sorted_array = sorted(array)
        
        # We will perform shifts until the array is sorted
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
                # Find the correct position of the current element
                correct_pos = sorted_array.index(array[i])
                
                # Perform a cyclic shift from i to correct_pos
                if i < correct_pos:
                    segment = array[i:correct_pos+1]
                    offset = correct_pos - i
                    shifted_segment = segment[offset:] + segment[:offset]
                    array[i:correct_pos+1] = shifted_segment
                    actions.append((i+1, correct_pos+1, offset))
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))
    
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(test_cases)
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of the array to the left by a specified offset. This operation is the only allowed modification to the array elements.

    'sort the array'
    Explanation: The goal is to rearrange the elements of the array in non-decreasing order using cyclic shifts.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n cyclic shifts'
    Explanation: The number of cyclic shifts used to sort the array should not exceed the length of the array, n. This means that for an array of length n, you can perform up to n shifts.

# [degree adverb]
    'minimal'
    Explanation: Refers to the smallest possible value or condition, such as when n is minimal or the array is already sorted. In this context, it implies that if the array is already sorted, no shifts are needed.

# [code logic]
1. For each test case, read the integer n and the array a.
2. Check if the array is already sorted. If it is, output k = 0 and no actions.
3. If not sorted, perform cyclic shifts:
   - Identify segments that can be shifted to bring elements closer to their sorted position.
   - For each segment, determine the optimal l, r, and d values to perform a left cyclic shift.
   - Record each shift operation.
4. Ensure that the total number of shifts does not exceed n.
5. Output the number of shifts and the details of each shift for each test case.

    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no shifts are needed.

Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of the array to the left by a specified offset, effectively rearranging the elements within that segment.

    'sort using cyclic shifts'
    Explanation: The task is to sort the array by performing cyclic shifts on segments of the array, ensuring the number of shifts does not exceed the length of the array.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n cyclic shifts'
    Explanation: The number of cyclic shifts performed to sort the array should not exceed the length of the array, n. This means we can perform up to n shifts.

# [degree adverb]
    'minimal'
    Explanation: Refers to the smallest possible value or size, in this context, it means considering edge cases where n is minimal (e.g., n = 2).

# [code logic]
    1. For each test case, check if the array is already sorted. If it is, output k = 0.
    2. If not sorted, identify segments that can be cyclically shifted to move elements into their correct positions.
    3. Perform cyclic shifts on identified segments, ensuring the number of shifts does not exceed n.
    4. Output the number of shifts and their descriptions for each test case.

# [edge case]
    Test case with already sorted array:
    Input: [1, 2]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no cyclic shifts are needed.

    Test case with minimal n:
    Input: [2, 1]
    Output: 1
    Explanation: Perform one cyclic shift on the segment [2, 1] to sort it.

    Test case with repeated elements:
    Input: [1, 2, 2, 1]
    Output: 1

# [extra code for edge case]

examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
